message_1: In a group of six people, what is the smallest number of connections needed for there to be either three mutual friends or three mutual strangers?
message_2:
To solve this problem, we can use the Pigeonhole Principle. We will consider each person as a "pigeonhole" and the connections between people as "pigeons."

Let's label the six people A, B, C, D, E, and F. We will start with person A.

Person A can have at most 5 connections with the other people in the group. Now, consider two cases:

Case 1: Person A has at least 3 friends (3 mutual connections).
In this case, if any of these 3 friends are also friends with each other, we have a group of 3 mutual friends. If none of these 3 friends are friends with each other, then they are all mutual strangers, and we have a group of 3 mutual strangers.

Case 2: Person A has at least 3 strangers (3 mutual non-connections).
In this case, if any of these 3 strangers are strangers to each other, we have a group of 3 mutual strangers. If all of these 3 strangers are friends with each other, then we have a group of 3 mutual friends.

In both cases, we can see that there must be either a group of 3 mutual friends or a group of 3 mutual strangers. Therefore, the smallest number of connections needed for there to be either three mutual friends or three mutual strangers in a group of six people is 3.
